metadata.title: Back Pain, Low  Chronic
anatomical location body part affected: Low back/lumbar vertebrae and intervertebral discs, lumbosacral and sacroiliac joints, spinal cord and the respective lumbar and sacral spinal nerves, ligamentum flavum, joint capsules of lumbar facets, longitudinal ligament, supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, posterior sacroiliac ligaments (long and short), iliolumbar ligaments, multifidus, and several trunk muscles with lumbosacral attachments: paraspinals, latissimus dorsi (via thoracolumbar fascia), gluteus maximus, quadratus lumborum, piriformis
description: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is characterized by musculoskeletal pain, tenderness, and restricted mobility in the lumbosacral area for more than 3 months. CLBP is a leading cause of disability, work absenteeism, and reduced health-related  quality of life (HRQOL).(18)Psychological factors may also impact disability and HRQOL in patients with CLBP(2)

CLBP may initially be treated conservatively which includes over the counter pain medication; modalities such as rest, ice, and heat. Physical therapy and core strengthening exercises may also be prescribed(18)

Strong evidence from RCTs supports appropriate therapeutic exercise and/or functional activities, patient education to continue ADLs as tolerated, and promotion of active self-management  in adults with CLBP. Programs that use aerobic training, strengthening, stretching/flexibility, trunk stabilization, or specific back exercises (that address normalizing lumbosacral movement) may each help reduce pain and disability in patients with CLBP(3)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Inquire about any ongoing legal claims, including workers’ compensation
presentation signs and symptoms: Pain and tenderness over the affected low back area lasting more than 3 months
Pain-restricted  back (especially lumbar) mobility, flexibility, strength, and ROM
Postural and gait disturbances due to altered movements of the trunk and lower extremities
Reduced physical functioning in ADLs  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Symptoms of cauda equina syndrome indicate a medical emergency that demands immediate evaluation and possibly surgery.(18) Cauda equina syndrome or myelitis from extreme nerve root compression due to traumatic injury, disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal neoplasm/metastatic tumor, or inflammation may result in permanent lower extremity paralysis and impairment of bowel and bladder function.(18) See CINAHL topic ID number T708499Cauda Equina Syndrome for more information on cauda equina syndrome

causes: Studies have shown that worldwide up to 23% of persons experienceCLBP(18)

Potential causes of CLBP that are exacerbated by mechanical loading of the affected body part and should be ruled out bythe physician include:–lumbar strain (i.e., indirect/nontraumatic muscle injury). However, this cause of LBP usually resolves within 3 months.See  Clinical Review ... Back Pain: Low, Acute  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709179 for review of LBP related tomuscle spasms–spinal derangement (often with nerve impingement) confirmed by radiographic evidence. See  Clinical Review ... Sciatica; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708763–discogenic disease: lumbar disc pathology (i.e., tear in annulus fibrosus, prolapse, herniation), lumbar degenerative discdisease (DDD) or spondylosis, lumbar spinal stenosis facet joint syndrome, sacroiliac joint dysfunction

Pathogenesis–Pathology of back pain generally depends on the etiology; however, most often it is caused by an acute inflammatoryprocess(18)–Although the cause of CLBP is considered nonspecific in most cases, one or more musculoskeletal conditions maycontribute to signs and symptoms-Lumbar strain-Overstretching and tearing of paraspinal muscle, as a result of excessive mechanical strain, can injure associatedtendons and ligaments-Abnormal spinal curvature such as in lumbar lordosis or scoliosis can place added strain on discs, ligaments, andsurrounding musculature-Lumbar DDD-Localized pain that might refer to the iliac crest or buttock area-Pain aggravated by activity and relieved with rest-Pain intensifies with cough or sneeze-Typically, symptoms develop gradually as the disc deteriorates-Lumbar spinal stenosis-Neurogenic claudication, CLBP, motor weakness, leg cramping, and sensation of “poor circulation” in lowerextremities(19)-Symptoms are aggravated by walking or lumbar extension and improve with lumbar flexion(19)-This usually is a degenerative condition. As DDD progresses, the intraspinal space decreases with disc bulging andinfolding of the ligamentum flavum, resulting in a narrowed spinal canal and nerve root foramen(19)-Facet joint syndrome-History of chronic spinal pain that has not responded to traditional therapies(20)-Localized tenderness and pain with side-bending  and, in some cases, spinal extension-Synovitis and degeneration of the vertebral facet joints with the development of arthritis, in conjunction with discthinning, is associated with CLBP(20)

Risk factors–Sedentary lifestyle and obesity can increase the risk of developing back pain(18)–Current and former cigarette smokers have a higher prevalence of LBP than persons who have never smoked. Theassociation between current smoking and LBP is strongest in adolescents(18)

overall contraindications precautions: Consult with physician on finding red flags associated with CLBP(18) Cauda equina syndrome Weakness Bowel/bladder incontinence Pain that disturbs sleep Malignancy  Fracture
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Symptoms of cauda equina syndrome indicate a medical emergency that demands immediate evaluation and possibly surgery.(18) Cauda equina syndrome or myelitis from extreme nerve root compression due to traumatic injury, disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal neoplasm/metastatic tumor, or inflammation may result in permanent lower extremity paralysis and impairment of bowel and bladder function.(18) See CINAHL topic ID number T708499Cauda Equina Syndrome for more information on cauda equina syndrome

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when the patient first experienced LBP. Was the onset sudden (e.g., trauma/incident) or gradual (e.g., with repetitive work or awkward postures)? Document the duration of CLBP (i.e., more than 3 months). How has the course of the pain changed?

course of treatment.medical management: Document the history of medical interventions used to treat back pain and the outcome of treatments
surgical management: Surgical management: Document any operative intervention (e.g., lumbar spinal fusion, laminectomy, discectomy) or invasive test (e.g., discography, medial branch block) for CLBP
course of treatment.medications: Document prescribed medications for CLBP and whether they are being taken and helping. Is the patient taking any nonprescribed painkillers, such as OTC NSAIDs, and are they helping manage the CLBP? Has the patient received cortisone epidural injections for relief of CLBP?
diagnostic tests completed: Imaging studies may not be performed during the first 6 weeks unless there is suspicion of other underlying etiology(18)
MRI may be performed in order to identify possible disc herniation or spinal stenosis(18)
Lumbar spine MRI is not considered to be of value in making a diagnosis based on specific spinal pathoanatomic changes(5)
In a 3-year  longitudinal study, annular fissures detected on MRI were associated with incident chronic LBP; however,
the 3year  incidence of these MRI findings was extremely low, and did not explain the symptoms in the vast majority of cases(5)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heat pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, chiropractic medicine) and whether they have helped
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other musculoskeletal conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Pain associated with lumbar DDD is aggravated by activity, coughing, and sneezing and is relieved with rest. Pain associated with facet joint disease commonly is aggravated by side-bending. Pain associated with lumbar spinal stenosis is aggravated by walking or lumbar spinal extension(19)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain associated with lumbar DDD is localized near the disc and may refer to the iliac crest or buttock. Pain associated with lumbar spine stenosis is located in the low back with cramping in the leg. Facet joint pain commonly is localized to the affected facet
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Symptoms include pain, tenderness, deep aching, weakness, and lower extremity cramping
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings per night and any sleep disturbances due to pain or disability
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., sudden worsening of symptoms, weight loss of unknown origin, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, night pain, pain at rest)(18)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient have any respiratory compromise? Does the patient smoke? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document whether patient has a history of a spinal derangement disorder or LBP (e.g., how long previous symptoms were present and number of recurrences) and any back surgeries
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask about other conditions, including history of surgical intervention for back problems, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, osteoporosis, and other orthopedic issues. Also document gastrointestinal symptoms, genitourinary symptoms, and general systemic complaints (e.g., fever, weight loss, peripheral joint symptoms)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken, including OTC drugs, for other medical conditions
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the patient participate in occupational activities or sports that he or she feels may contribute to CLBP? What kind of repetitive work habits does patient perform? What posture does patient have to maintain throughout his or her work day?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight. Determine BMI and whether patient is overweight or obese. Measure for leg-length  discrepancy, as indicated by posture assessment
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document whether patient uses a lumbar support or any assistive devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static/dynamic balance in sitting and standing. Use Berg Balance Scale (BBS) for objective measure of balance deficits as indicated –Balance may be impaired in individuals with CLBP(15)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulsesObserve body mechanics in general mobility, such as lifting and carrying, and during ADLs or work activities. Perform an ergonomic assessment of the patient’s workstation, as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess general motor function using FIM. Ask patient to demonstrate the gross movements that are possible without pain limitation. Assess bed mobility and ability in transfers, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for gait abnormalities (e.g., asymmetric pattern in stride length). Heel walking and toe walking may indicate L5 root involvement and S1 root involvement, respectivelyAssess mobility of thoracic and lumbar spine with posterior-to-anterior  glides as indicated and appropriate. Clear/rule out involvement of the hip and sacroiliac joints
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess bilateral lower extremity and trunk strength with manual muscle testing (MMT) per patient’s tolerance. Assess ability to activate the transverse abdominis, lumbar multifidus, and erector spinae muscles
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Note any abnormal spinal curvature (i.e., scoliosis, kyphosis, or lordosis) –Assess for leg-length  symmetry and symmetry of iliac crests
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess bilateral lower extremity ROM –Document reproduction of pain –In standing, assess forward bending, measuring distance from fingertips to the floor. While patient is flexed, view from behind to detect scoliosis and from the side to detect persistent lumbar lordosis, indicative of protective muscle guarding –Measure trunk extension, rotation, and side-bending  to the right and left. Pain while bending toward the affected side may indicate disc disease, and pain while bending away from affected side may indicate a muscular strain(18) –Test for flexibility of hamstrings, iliotibial bands, quadriceps, piriformis, and hip flexors and rotators (e.g., using 90-90 SLR and Ober, Ely, and Thomas tests)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Check lower extremity reflexes in sitting position, including patellar and Achilles reflexes. Hyporeflexia indicates lower motor neuron involvement. Hyperreflexia indicates upper motor neuron involvement
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Perform sensory testing along lower extremity dermatomes, including pinprick, light touch, and temperature
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Questionnaire or Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) –McGill Pain Questionnaire (MPQ) –Dallas Pain Questionnaire –Borg Back Pain Intensity Scale –Aberdeen Low Back Pain Scale –Roland-Morris  Disability Questionnaire –High predictive screening tools for CLBP(16) -STarT Back Screening Tool -Orebro Musculoskeletal Pain Questionnaire –The 36-item  Short-Form  Health Survey (SF-36)  is a physical functioning dimension of HRQOL

contraindications precautions: Acute cervical trauma, including whiplash-associated  disorders
Use of steroids or other medications that tend to compromise bone integrity
Rheumatologic disorders affecting connective tissue, including rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis
Patients with COPD or other respiratory disorders
Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation or poor circulation, or slow-healing  wounds
Use caution with patients who are hypertensive as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor is present in the area
In the area of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
Over epiphyseal plates of growing bones
Use caution in patients with sensory deficits and in patients who are unable to communicate sensory deficits
Use caution if patient has circulatory impairments
Use caution over plastic or metal implants
Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls due to the potential for postural changes and pain-related  loss of balance. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Avoid bed rest longer than 2 or 3 days during periods of increased mechanical pain
Tailor the exercise prescription according to the patient’s functional ability and exertional symptoms
Provide close patient supervision and instruction to perform exercise sessions with proper back posture and body mechanics
Provide a thorough orientation to use of therapeutic exercise equipment and adequate warm-up  time to help reduce apprehension about exercise
Modify exercises to minimize exercise-related  back pain
Clinicians should follow the exercise guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician
Contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis regarding use of modalities are listed below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in decision-making

Electrotherapy  contraindications or precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below provided potential benefits outweigh the possible risks)(1)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CLBP/pain; reduced mobility, strength and endurance; deficits in posture and body mechanics; modified or altered ADLs
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Lumbar spine stenosis, spinal tumors, ankylosing spondylitis, myelitis, and cauda equina syndrome Lumbosacral muscle strains/sprains Tumor(18) Infection(18) Idiopathic scoliosis(18) Psychological disorder (conversion, somatization disorder)(18) Scheuermann’s kyphosis(18) Malingering/secondary gains
prognosis: Factors associated with worse outcomes for LBP include:(18) –Prior history of back pain –Greater intensity of back pain –Presence of leg or widespread symptoms –BMI > 25 –Smoking –Depression and catastrophizing thoughts –Fear-avoidance  behavior
Overall, the vast majority of persons who experience LPB improve and it does not impact a person’s quality of life or function in the long term(18)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplinesreferring physician, consulting surgeon, pain management specialist, psychologist, dietitian, social worker, occupational therapist, physical therapist, acupuncturist, and vocational rehabilitation counselor Orthopedic surgeon or neurosurgeon for consultation regarding possible or recurrent disc herniation, spinal stenosis, or segmental lumbar instability
other considerations: Authors of a 2015 Cochrane review with meta-analysis  of 41 RCTs (N = 6,858) found that a combination of physical and behavioral treatments (i.e., multidisciplinary biopsychosocial rehabilitation) was more effective (moderate evidence) than usual care or stand-alone  physical treatments (low-quality  evidence) for decreasing pain and improving function in patients with CLBP(2)

Authors of a systematic review conducted in 2020 found that mechanical traction therapy for the treatment of LBP provides significant pain reduction and improves functional improvements in the short term, but these effects are not sustained over the long term(17)

Pain neuroscience education (PNE) combined with physiotherapy interventions has been show to improve disability and pain in persons with CLBP(13) –PNE is used for educational purposes in order to educate a person’s understanding of pain –The goal is to change a person’s perception of where pain comes from in order toreduce fear avoidance behavior
treatment summary: Exercise therapy –Authors of a 2015 meta-analysis  of 39 RCTs found that strength/resistance training and coordination/stabilization training were significantly more effective than other exercise interventions for reducing CLBP and that cardiorespiratory and combined exercise programs were ineffective(3) -This meta-analysis  compared 4 different groups of activities to determine the most effective program for treating CLBP: -Strength / resistance group which focused on movements of the major muscle groups to improve strength -Coordination / stabilization group which focused on activities on balance, agility, coordination, gait, and proprioception -Cardiorespiratory group performed regular, purposeful, and continuous exercises that involved the major muscle groups -The combined group was defined in this study as a combination of strengthening, stretching, endurance, and aerobic training exercises, which also included modalities such as yoga, pilates, and cesar therapy (posture and movement therapy) -The results of this study show that the strengthening and resistance group had a small, but significant benefit for non-specific  CLBP; coordination and stabilization exercises provide a reduction in pain as a result of improved lumbo-pelvic  stability; cardiorespiratory programs had no effect in reducing CLBP pain -The overall consensus is that, participating in a strengthening and resistance training program combined with performing coordination and stabilization had a significant improvement in reducing pain in patients with CLBP –Pilates and McKenzie exercises have been found to reduce pain in patients with CLBP(9) –Hip strengthening exercises, particularly those that target the hip abductors, extensors, and external rotators,improve pain and disability in persons with LBP(14)

Physical and electrotherapeutic modalities –Although there is conflicting findings regarding the effectiveness of ultrasound (US) for LBP, based on the current evidence the best treatment is US. The recommended frequency should be set to 1 MHZ with an intensity rating of 1 –2 W/cm2 with a duration of 10 minutes(1)

Manual therapy –Authors of a 2015 Cochrane review and meta-analysis  of 12 RCTs (N = 500) found low-quality  evidence that the muscle energy technique (MET) was not effective for reducing pain or disability in patients with LBP(16)

Foot orthoses or insoles –Authors of a 2014 systematic review of 5 trials (N = 293) found insufficient evidence to support the use of insoles or foot orthoses for alleviating signs or symptoms in patients with LBP(4)

Authors of a single-blind  RCT researched the effects of a mind-body  program on patients with CLBP and found short-term improvements in function and pain associated with this intervention(6) –Two hundred eighty-two  patients with CLBP were randomized to the mind-body group (N = 140) or control group (N = 142) –Both groups received treatment for 8 weeks followed by 6 monthly sessions –The mind-body  program focuses on stress reduction techniques as well as meditation techniques. The mind-body  program incorporates regular physical activities such as walking, sitting, and lying down and encourages patients to also meditate through direct breathing and be aware of their thoughts and sensations –Results show short-term  improvements in overall function; however, results were not sustained in the long term

Pilates –Participation in a Pilates program can reduce pain and improve posture in patients with CLBP(7) -Based on an RCT study in Italy -Thirty-eight  individuals with CLBP were randomized to either the Pilates group or control group -The Pilates group performed a pre-established  Pilates program for 50 minutes supervised by a sports and exercise specialist, 3 times per week for 14 weeks -Primary outcome measures used in this study were the ODI and posturography analysis –Participation in an 8-week  Pilates-based  exercise program may result in decreased pain and disability and improved flexibility and balance in persons with nonspecific LBP(11) -Based on an RCT in Spain -54 patients with chronic nonspecific LBP were randomized to either an experimental Pilates exercise program (N = 27) or control group (N = 27) -Control group received information via a leaflet about posture, physical activity, weight lifting, fear movements, and active lifestyle -Pilates group exercise consisted of two 45-minute  sessions a week for 8 weeks. Exercises consisted of floor exercises on a 55cm ball, traditional Pilates exercises, and stretching exercises -Pilates participants were also taught how to fire their pelvic floor, transversus abdominis, and multifidus muscles

Pilates Training for 6 weeks may minimize the risk for falls and improve functional balance and pain in older women with CLBP(8) –Based on an RCT in Spain -Ninety-seven  women were randomized to either the Pilates plus PT group (N = 50) or PT only (N = 47) -Both groups received standard physical therapy twice weekly for 6 weeks, but the Pilates group received an additional treatment session twice a week for 60 minutes -Outcome measures used in this study included the Falls Efficacy Scale– International (FES-I),  TUG, and the NRS pain scale

Authors of a 2020 systematic review found that yoga therapy, taichi, and qigong can improve functional ability and reduce the pain and psychological distresses associated with LBP(12) –Based on 32 studies that met inclusion criteria .
